reviewText:
Early Access Review

Warside is a fast and fun arcade-style game with rpg elements that you can enjoy for free.  In fact, it wasn't until after I had already spent about 60 hours playing that I finally decided to go ahead and and purchase the $10 base game.  The $10 was well spent as I now have a permanent XP/credits/rewards bonus which is very beneficial as your character levels get into the teens.

Getting Started
Before you can actually start playing the game you have to choose your character type from 1 of 4 options.  The main differences between the different types aside from appearance include the base attributes and type of special movement.
Faceless: starts with high speed / low attack, can double-jump and hang on walls
Guardian: starts with high armor / low speed, antigrav allows you to float around
Huntress: starts with high attack / low armor, can dash through the air with great speed
Mercenary: is the most balanced to start with, uses a JetpackOnce you choose a character type you have to choose your class:
Defender: Tank class - High armor and defense
Preferred weapons: LMG, handgun
Gadgets: stationary shield, extended shield Assault: Main damage class. High attack capabilities
Preferred weapons: assault rifles, melee
Gadgets: rocket, stationary turret Infiltrator: Damage class with some control abilities
Preferred weapons: sniper rifle, shotgun
Gadgets: poison dart, stunning trap Destroyer: Damage class focusing on area damage
Preferred weapons: rocket launcher, flamethrower
Gadgets: grenade, mine Medic: Healer class
Preferred weapons: charger, SMGsNext you customize the appearance of your character and name them.  Finally, you choose from 1 of 3 factions, which are kind of pointless for now unless you want to play with friends in which case you should join the same one.

Multiplayer
When I first started playing this game I was routinely playing with other humans but in the time since the player base has decreased and I find myself usually playing with bots.  It's still a lot of fun though because you can get a great kill-death ratio and a lot of XP.  At the same time, this game is at its best when you have a human teammate to join forces with.

Game Modes
Typically you'll end up playing PVP, with any unused player slots being filled in bots.  There is also a co-op vs AI level which is a ton of fun if you can find coop players.  The last mode is a last stand type game mode where you and your team must survive waves of enemies.  Unfortunately, the last 2 game modes don't come into rotation often.

Gameplay
The gameplay is fun enough to warrant playing as all of the character types and different classes.  Though it is not perfect and may take some getting used to, movement and weapons work well.  Rounds typically last 10-15 minutes and are fast paced.  Gameplay basically consists of trying to get as many kills as possible and/or capturing/holding control points while watching your shields and taking defensive actions to allow your shield to recharge in order to avoid getting killed.

Levels/Stages/Maps
The different stages are excellent and there are numerous.  They are nicely rendered, visually appealing and contain tons of small details that keep them from feeling empty.  There are also certain areas where teams tend to cluster which turn into corridors for epic battles.

The stages do a good job of creating a flow that pits teams against eachother, particularly on the conquest game mode.  You will also have to change your play style depending on your character type and class due to their inherent strengths and weaknesses, and movement type, all of which makes for more variety.

Weapons
Assault rifles, sniper rifles, LMGs, SMGs, missile launchers, flame throwers, pistols, shotguns and a device for charging teammates shields.  You can also carry 2 gadgets such as a rocket launcher or grenade launcher, poison dart, shields, defensive stations, auto-turrets, traps and more.  There are also attachments you can add to each weapon to add secondary fire modes and increased range, damage, accuracy, etc.

Upgrades
The main motivator for progressing in this game is upgrades.  Armor/weapon upgrades, weapon attachments, offensive/defensive gadgets/abilities, cybernetic implants, unique appearances and more.  All items require you to be a certain level to use and the tiers are laid out well enough so that you'll always be working towards the next tier of upgrades.

Shops
You can buy weapons, armor, etc. from shops and the market.  The regular shop sells the basic stuff which is easy to afford and good enough to get you through.  The faction shop sells the good stuff, but everything costs faction currency which is a commodity you collect by completing achievements.  Finally, the market is where players can go to sell their own items and buy from others, as such you can find some very useful and rare things here when the player base is active.

Crafting
Using recipes and special components, you can craft special and rare weapons and armor.  I think the recipes cost too much in the faction shop but if you're lucky someone may sell what you want on the market.

Special Abilities
As you level up you can build out your skill tree which enhances your stats and opens up special abilities.  For example, as an infiltrator with a sniper rifle you can gain abilities which make your next shot do the same damage as a headshot or lower your enemies defense.

User Interface
The user interface doesn't explain in great detail exactly how you are supposed to do everything but it's easy enough to figure out as you advance through the game.  The game didn't originally support the English language so there are some spelling and grammar discrepancies but nothing too bad.

Audio
The music is well done and very fitting though sometimes I turn it off to play my own.  Weapon sound effects are sufficient.  There was a bug where the reloading sound would get stuck in a loop but the devs quickly fixed it.

Developers/Staff/Community
The staff of the game has been vocal in the community, open to suggestions and accommodating to the player-base.  The community is small but includes some great people.

Footnote
Some of my information about character types and classes has been gleaned from http://www.indiedb.com/games/warside/features/warside-factions-character-types-and-classes-revealed

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Warside, a game I was extremely hyped for due to me personally being a fan of Platform Shooters. Having only played 4 hours of this game as of this review, I obviously haven't seen everything. However, I still feel that I can recommend it to other fans of the Platform Shooter. If anyone's played the Platform Shooter Raze and its sequels, I find this game comparable and more well polished.

Game Types: From what I've seen there are several currently available game modes put into two sections, PvP and PvE. Pretty standard so far. PvP currently has Team Deathmatch, Domination, and Gathering (Collecting/stealing Crystals from your enemy team to improve score) under its belt. While PvE has Siege (Wave Defense) and Mission, which so far seems to be almost like the story line where you battle a total of three bosses and rooms full of enemies. And these are the only missions I currently have access to being a Level 5. None of them have gotten personally repeditive, and I always get a good laugh out of a game whenever my body ragdolls across the map (I should add I'm terrible at this game, but love it anyway.)

Weapons/Gear: I'll only briefly go into this, as there are a ton (Well, enough for a Platformer like this) of weapons and gear to choose from to fix your play style. Weapons spread from Melee, Sidearms, SMG, Shotguns, Assault Rifles, Machine Guns, Rocket Launchers, Snipers, and Flamethrowers. All weapons have durability which will degrade after every battle, but repairs are extremely cheap and can easily be covered in one game 10 times over. Note that costs will go up with weapon rarity. There are also Wrist weapons/Gear that can be equipped to deal damage over time or adding an additional defense to defend you and your team.

RPG Elements: Yes, Warside has its fair share of RPG elements to add alittle bit of character customization. There is currently a limited skill tree which has passive effects for weapons and gear. These effects can add additional AoE damage to an explosive weapon, adding armor and speed bonuses, or adding duration to Poison Darts and Traps.

There is also a Player Market which functions the same as it does in most other ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes.

But in conclusion, I recommend the game to those who like RPGs and Platformers as it has a decent mix at the moment, which will without a doubt grow as the game flies through Early Access. Be sure to also make a few friends and create a private group, the one annoy quality (to me) is the very long matchmaking, which I'm sure is being worked on.

EDIT: The game is not Pay to Win by any means, it's Pay for Convenience. I've personally been able to survive with two characters and limited Gear space. But  If you want to get more Gear/EXP in one mission, feel free to spend money, otherwise farm you weapons and levels (which isn't very hard.)
Yes, there are alot of bugs, but believe it or not, I've yet to come across any at all. Either Kraken Games is doing a good job or I'm just really lucky :)

Warside, this game looked great when it was not avalable on Steam quite yet, and it's now here for our enjoyment. As per my usual I will be rating the game on a 0 to 10 scale on multiple aspects

Graphics: 9/10: For a 2d Shmup, this game looks gorgeous! For an Early Access game, it's pretty polished on graphics, though there are a few hiccups like things un-rendering when the camera gets far enough away, but that's nothing too bad.

Sound: ?/10: Ok, I could not with the default settings even hear the music, and sound effects, and turning everything up made the game tell me it had to restart, so I just played without the sounds, I can give a better review on them later after turning everything up. I could though faintly hear gunshot noises.

Gameplay: 7.5/10: Ok, so this game has no Weapon Rental gimmics, which is really nice. Everything in the Cash Shop looks to be cosmetic, which is also really nice. The gameplay itself is pretty good, there's a few things that need to be tweaked, and the developer that was online has said they are addressing things, which is amazing for a game dev!

1. Collision in PvP: Currently you can collide with enemies and friendlies alike in PvP, which is very annoying for a 2d Game, if it was a 3d or even 2.5d i'd be less inclined to see this as an issue, but they are toying with making no collision.

2. Friendly Fire in PvE: I didn't ask a question about this one, as I just got out of the game after doing 1 PvE mission, because I had other things to do, but Friendly Fire is Enabled in PvE and it's hella annoying.

3. Gun physics: 90% of the weapons in this game drop like rocks, the only exceptions are Bolt Action Rifles, Dart Launchers, and Rocket Launchers. And that's not good.

Overall: 8/10: If the sound issues were resolved, and the 3 concerns were addressed, this game would be great! If you are looking for a 2d shoot-em-up this is a great option compared to say Boring Man.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The gameplay is pretty decent, although the aiming, bullet physics, and character movements are hella floaty. Anything remotely resembling platforming and hazards, precise movement is a must. Even with the occasional bugs that prevent a match from even loading or beginning, or even finishing, it's still worth a shot. It is f2p. Using real money doesn't happen to be a necessity from what i was able to gather.

The thing that caused me to call it quit's for this game is just the sheer lack of content at this given moment, and the ♥♥♥♥ poor matchmaking system. You could end up spending 5-10 min on average just to get one multiplayer session started. This is because the timer resets when ever a player connects, drops, or changes their matchmaker settings. There will be times it will be at the last couple seconds before showtime, then someone just happens to do something outside of simply waiting and hitting the ready button. This screws it up for everyone whom was actually being patient.

To summarize. Fun game, as long as you play multiplayer. Goodluck with getting a match going though.

Edit: So it's been about 9-10 months since i last tried this game. I was hoping at this point that there would be enough fixes and additional content to make the redownload worth while. Even better would be to have an active community. Sadly neither of these scenarios are the case. Even worse is now i get trapped at the HUB screen for an eternity once i try to access anything. A little loading dial appears on the cursor and never goes away. I figured at first this was my internet, it wasn't. Upon restarting the game, i'd get further through the menus each time till i finally got to the point of setting up a match. However, there is no one to play with.

With how slow this game is progressing in its development, if anything is being done at all, it's going to be another year till it might be in an enjoyable state. As of right now, i still can't change my recommendation.

It's really just a flash game remade to be 2.5 D and placed on Steam. Now that isn't entirely a bad thing but I just couldn't get past the visuals and more importantly the feel. For all the fancy movement my character (Faceless) could do it mostly seemed pointless as some enemies just wouldn't die by my weaponry, so spinning while jumping had little effect at dodging theirs. They had no healer or sheild generator but I could clearly see that they would take AGES to die. I hit them with a rocket at point-blank range and it was barely anything against them.

Visually, the art work is more impressive than anything else. I see the character model and barely can make out what I'm wearing or if it's even well modeled at all. There wasn't anything visually striking or interesting about the maps. Simple standard choke points and obvious areas for team fights. Then you have the stupidly OPEN maps with all these areas to cling to and mess about with, meanwhile I just want to get to the action quickly not act like a mouse trying to get to the end of the maze for cheese.

Load times are weirdly long for what doesn't seem like a very taxing game. There are times where I felt like Far Cry 4 or Skyrim loaded faster than this thing.

Instead of it being a fast paced run and gun game, it ends up being all about who can bunker down in a single area and fire the best stream of bullets in 1 direction. So PvP was a bust even if I got kills, it wasn't exactly fun". It was just... I got some kills and suddenly the match was over.

I don't know how to do reviews so here a good recipe for banana bread

2-3 very ripe bananas, peeled
1/3 cup melted butter
1 cup of sugar (can easily use 3/4 cup, or drop it down to 1/2 cup if you want it less sweet)
1 egg, beaten
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1 teaspoon baking soda
Pinch of salt
1 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour
METHOD
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C), and butter a 4x8-inch loaf pan.
In a mixing bowl, mash the ripe bananas with a fork until smooth. Stir the melted butter into the mashed bananas.
Mix in the baking soda and salt. Stir in the sugar, beaten egg, and vanilla extract. Mix in the flour.
Pour the batter into your prepared loaf pan. Bake for 1 hour to 1 hour 10 minutes (check at 50 minutes) at 350°F (175°C), or until a tester inserted into the center comes out clean.
Remove from oven and cool completely on a rack. Remove the banana bread from the pan. Slice and serve. (A bread knife helps to make slices that aren't crumbly.)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI understand this game is early access and there will be bugs but man, this game is pretty bad as is. Supposedly player levels scale with the battle but thats BS, have fun getting 1-2 shot by players at least six levels higher when you start. Want to do PVE? Have fun with half of your team leaving as soon as the match starts. The concept is nice, I'll give them that, kinda feels like a mix between Abuse and Awesomenauts but as it stands with the horrible lag, almost nonexistent community and ♥♥♥♥ balance I really can't recommend this game. I mean come on, how fair is it for someone to be able to stand on a capture point and take no damage because they're a higher level? Maybe if they work out some of the very blatant issues the game could be decent but with this being a russian free to play game you can't expect much from it. No, I'm not stereotyping it's just an observation, every russian game I have ever played has been a bug riddled poorly designed mess but maybe thats just me and I haven't found any of the good ones yet. As for the gameplay, you run, jump, doublejump, jetpack or hover your way around the map, movement feels nice but the animations leave a lot to be desired. When my character starts running it feels like they are going to fall over from how much they lean plus it makes all of your bullets go toward the ground no matter where you aim. Oh and speaking of aiming, it feels very bad, they have this invisible circle around your character that your mouse pointer stays in, it feels very bad for anyone that has played a 2D sidescrolling shooter as you want to put your reticle on what you're aiming at but simply can't due to the way they have it set up. Melee combat feels like you're slapping the enemy with a soggy piece of bread, there is no indication that you're even hitting your target and it feels awkward as hell. The shooting is okay but with the whole aiming issue it makes things a bit more complicated than they should be. I could keep typing for hours about all of the issues but I'd rather not. Try it yourself if you don't believe me, maybe you'll have a better experience than I.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QKRyN0NsDQs
Warside is a new free to play on Steam, but is this game worth jumping into?  Let's take a quick first impression review of Warside.

Warside is a 2D player vs player based shooter with an RPG like progression system.  The game has a lot of customization.  You choose from one of four characters that each have different types of movement advantages and base attributes.  Then you select a class type which effects your role during matches as well as your initial loadout.  Customization only allows changing the head and facial features, you can't adjust the body at all.

The game will then run you through the tutorial level which is one of the most bland tutorials I've ever experienced.  It runs you through the basic movement, shooting, and traversal.  The game controls with WASD for movement and the mouse for aiming and shooting.  You have a jetpack for platforming and fast movement.

After the tutorial you can jump straight into a match.  The gameplay resembles capture the flag but with multiple items to collect.  You fight on the battlefield as you bring these supplies back to your base.  Combat is hectic and clunky.  Just look at this battle here.  You have multiple players crashing into each other shooting blindly.  There is no strategy and the movement is so difficult to control.  Even platforming starts to become uncomfortable while you are trying to chase down enemies and find supplies.

The economy and microtransaction restrict from doing most things you want to do as in any free to play.  You'll have to make purchases to change your character class, appearance, or even create a second character.

Furthermore I had the game crash on me several times in just a few hours of play.   I also can't hit 60 frames per second in this game even though my beast of a PC can run Dying Light on Ultra at 60 frames per second.  The interface is very unintuitive and not as responsive as it should be.  The button to start the match is this green button.  I can't even tell what that says.  I understand this game is Early Access, but this is beyond unpolished.  It's unplayable.  I can't recommend Warside, you should skip this game until they fix the bugs and make the game much more intuitive.

Negatives
-Clunky Controls
-Unresponsive Interface
-Poor Graphics / Poor Performance
